Disgusting the amount of money this company has and this is how they spend it - wasting everyone’s time with a disgusting glitched buggy system so Youcan sell something on the market with no hold. Evaluate yourselves whoever made this thing it’s literally pathetic that you could even think you’ve done a good job here. Go work at McDonald’s it’s all you’ll ever be good for.

Steam Mobile.title: Fantastic App!
Steam Mobile.body: Works great, occasionally some server issues, but otherwise it's fantastic. Apart from Steam Chat, and the Steam Store built into the app, there's a few features hidden away such as managing downloads remotely (handy if you buy a game through the app while away, and want to queue it for downloads), and Steam Chat providing up-to-date messages so you don't have to go into the steam overlay to talk to friends. Looking forward to future updates!

Steam Mobile.title: Can’t see game screenshots in the app.
Steam Mobile.body: If I’m deciding whether to buy a game, I want to see images of the gameplay in landscape, as portrait makes the game images (which are all landscape) way to small to appreciate any of the game’s graphics—basically no way to see the product properly in the app. The header and footer also cover way too much of the screen in landscape mode, so even just trying to view the images on the page is not possible.

Steam Mobile.body: Not ready for release as the app is so buggy it is barely usable

Steam Mobile.title: If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it!
Steam Mobile.body: It used to be a good app… now it is just a sales tool that pulls data from the web site (30% of the time it can; 70% it will say try again!). They also removed STEAM chat from the app & put it in another app; but didn’t let you know.Its only use really is checking on comments, but most of the time you need to reload it to get the data & it has a horrid interface where you often can only see the last message.Can we have the old one back please that worked really well for years.

Steam Mobile.title: Beta impressions
Steam Mobile.body: The layout of friends, profile info and game catalogues is done very well. Steam Mobile.title: Steam customer service is “steam”ing alright

So when it comes to authentication I just use the app… oh wait the app randomly logs me out of it anyways and then asks me to authenticate myself with the app!! Excellent!! Also why does it seem like the Steam help personnel think that freaking super villains are trying to hack my account? Why should I have to remember the entire debit card information I used 4 freakin’ years ago to confirm that I am who I say I am? I would love a 24-hr help line where I could just talk to someone instead of sending a dumb little form over the internet that takes 2 days to get back to me with a reply with a question that no normal person can possibly answer. The help center needs improvement because at its current state I think I would rather just off myself!

Steam Mobile.title: Completely broken
Steam Mobile.body: In general I’m a fan of Steam, but this app is a mess. I’ve always put up with minor bugs, like not being able to click on search results (the screen would just refresh instead of opening the game page), but after changing my password on my pc the app is now completely unusable. At first it wouldn’t let me in at all, then after disabling the app based authenticator and logging out on all devices, I can now get in, but nothing works. Everything I try to do now causes the app to attempt to verify my login, then times out. And every time I close the app, I’m logged out entirely again.  I can still log in on my pc and phone’s browser with zeros issues, so the app is definitely the issue. I’ve tried reinstalling it multiple times, and even logging in with different accounts, and the result is the same — the app is fried.I filed a ticket, so we’ll see what support has to say, but given the lack of support other users are getting with this buggy mess of an app, I’m not hopeful. A company this big, profitable, and successful needs to do better.

Steam Mobile.title: Account changes break the app
Steam Mobile.body: I had to change my password while the app had the authenticator active using the app. First of all, it would not let me do this using the app even though everything on the website redirects you to the app. It asks you to confirm the password change using the app, but since it’s basically loading a webpage within the app itself it never registers that you’re already in the app and you can’t confirm anything.Second, when you finally change your password using a browser and app combo, if you have the authenticator active on the app, the app completely breaks. You’re still “logged in” using the old password, but since your password has changed nothing works because your credentials are wrong. It also won’t let you log out because the authenticator is active. This problem continues even after you remove the authenticator from your account using a browser.For as much money as steam has you’d think they could afford to pay someone with competence to not have everything fall apart when you try to simply change your password. It’s like the steam webpage, authenticator, and app are all made by separate conpanies in separate countries and nobody speaks the same language or has any way to communicate with each other. Pathetic.

Steam Mobile.title: Terrible, only get if you have to.
Steam Mobile.body: Terrible App. You’d think they would have at least a semi-decent app but you can trust the App Store reviews for sure on this one. Actual trash. I’m completely locked out from using the app with my account or any account for that matter. I changed my password because someone logged into my account from another country, and now it has me in a non-stop loop of trying to log me in and acting like it did, not actually logging me in though, verifying my account info when I’m trying to go on community page/look at my profile, and then giving me the same error message over and over. Sometimes, the screen just freezes gray in the app and I can’t do anything in the app unless I delete the app and re-download, AND THEN it still only works for a little bit before it starts crashing again. To top it all off, because I’ve been trying to log in since I’m trying to verify that everything in my account is OKAY after someone tried getting into it, I have been locked out of my account for trying to login too many times. I still don’t know if my account’s okay. Not worth the migraine.

Steam Mobile.title: Very polished, but a couple issues
Steam Mobile.body: The majority of the bugs that used to exist in this new app have been patched, which gives this new app a very polished experience. There is still one bug which kind of translates into 2, which is the scaling of UI elements. For people who use larger on screen text for accessibility or have a smaller screen size, the app just breaks. Buttons to accept Steam Guard confirmations don’t fit on the screen and the app can’t be properly used. Landscape mode also works on phones, even though it really should only work on iPads. If you try to tilt your phone sideways on the Steam Guard screen, things get crazy. And the notch blocks things as well.I also wish the video player would be fixed too, you have to tap where you think the unmute button is, and then tap to go fullscreen, but you just get a black window. You then have to close the video and re enter it repeatedly until it works in fullscreen, which is very aggravating. This is on iOS 15 on an iPhone 12.

Steam Mobile.title: Years of absolute frustration
Steam Mobile.body: For the record, I was a early adopter of STEAM for PC. I have a long standing account and a huge library. I was excited for this app when it came out. But after years of constant frustration I’m done with it. It’s amazing how you guys can make your PC app work flawlessly 98% of the time but cannot seem to fix the blatant issues with this iOS app. Today I was locked in family view. I could access everything fine through PC. I could even access family view settings with my family view password. However, I still couldn’t get to the store page because it kept giving me a error for validating the password. I removed and reloaded app and it just became worse. Got it to work once and then black screen of death. Delete/reload again (3times) to same effect. I’m done with this disaster and having to use it for steam guard for the safest version of steam guard is a joke.  I’m convinced you folks don’t care because it’s been a craptastic app since it’s inception!

Steam Mobile.title: The new version adds much needed features but…
Steam Mobile.body: I really like a lot of the new features added in the recent overhaul, being able to redeem codes in the app itself is a huge plus. That said, it’s clear this update was not made with iPads in mind, there’s no support for Landscape orientation. There are major issues with the search function too, typing into the bar doesn’t offer suggestions and tapping return just clears the bar without taking you into a search page. This means i cannot actually search the store within the app. Which, given that this is a storefront first and foremost, is a major problem. With those issues fixed, this is a 5-star app easy. But until then, i can only give it a 3. Please fix this soon!EDIT: landscape support has been added and makes the app much more functional but the search bar still does not work at all, this needs to be fixed asap

Steam Mobile.title: An underwhelming experience
Steam Mobile.body: It has come far from the days of just messaging people or opening up steam pages and crashing, so I thought with this new update it might be able to breath new air into the app. I was half right, the update/overhaul to the UI and some needed QOL of changes such as not crashing anytime I do something have been helpful and while the UI feels cleaner and less clunky; I cannot say the same for its navigation experience. Often times I will be wanting to wishlist or buy games and the icons simply won’t register being clicked and it isn’t very clear that clicking on a title vs clicking on the thumbnail will warrant a different result. Search bar is mediocre, often clicking multiple links within the app confuses it and can result in certain processes not loading and requiring a hard reset. In conclusion the app has lots of potential but as of now it’s a 6/10 from me.

Steam Mobile.title: Data Breach for hacker bots
Steam Mobile.body: I have a new computer that made a steam account a year ago. I bought seven games to start. Someone signed into their 10 year old account on my device and now I see over a hundred servers in tools and every game they own on MY account. They then uninstalled my two games on my computer from their account. It’s like steam switched the accounts. They then deleted their 10 year account. (It’s in the process of being deleted.) When I sign into my account I see all their games and tools. When they sign into their account, that’s being deleted, they see only two games, mine. We can’t stop steam from hijacking my computer doing whatever they want. So technically right now they are deleting my new account, and then they expect me to autoupdate over 100 game servers from the account that signed into my device. This is a disaster for anyone with cptsd from hacking abuse like me. I guess in the end I can’t use steam at all because they ignore you when you’re telling them what’s going on. My new account is banned from participating in the community when I’ve never even talked to anyone because I have no friends. Thanks to steam for compromising my brand new computer and thanks for forcing me off your platform for no reason at all. To those reading this never let anyone else sign in on your computer even your sibling or they will switch the accounts and destroy your computer. And never let your mom and dad put you and your sibling on the same authentication.

The problem is what happens when you click it?  What? 4 more less-than-intuitive steps? 5?"Download and install Adobe digital edition (“ADE”) on your computer. You need this free software in order to unlock and read your ebook. (More info about installing ADE.)“Authorize” Adobe Digital Editions: With the program open on your computer,click Help >Authorize >select Adobe ID as your eBook vendor and then >type in your Adobe user name and password, or create an Adobe ID if you don’t have one." eBooks.title: My only eBook store since I got fed up with Kobo
eBooks.body: I only use ebooks.com for ebooks now. They're rated high on the ethics lists and they don't tie you in to a format or their own software. Having said that, you can use their reader - I've had a poke round it and it looks simple and well-designed but I like ereaders and don't have a tablet, so I just download the epubs. They use ADE for DRM, which is the worst software from the worst software company, but there's nothing they can do about that: Adobe have a monopoly on epub sales and it's still preferable to using Amazon.Other than that, it's a decent website with an efficient search facility and I can usually find what I want in one search. For browsing, it's as good as any books website and doesn't try to direct your choices. That tendency to push particular product was what made me look for an alternative to Kobo, and ebooks.com is much better for just drifting through webpages, looking for an interesting title.I'm pretty happy with them. I read paper books as well - I can recommend thehive.co.uk for them - so I don't buy as many ebooks as some people, but I've been spending a lot of  time on the site, planning my next series read after I finish Val McDermid, and it has become a favourite website.All in all, I thoroughly recommend them.

For me the key is using  Calibre ebook management software so I don't have to be tied to Adobe's lame reader. This way I can load my books from ebook.com on my Kindle (which... as much as hate to admit it is the still the best reader) without having to invest in Jeff's off world exit strategy. It's one more step but it's really not very difficult. To be honest having multiple propriety ebookstores and readers was really annoying. Now I use eBooks.com and I get the satisfaction reading what I have paid for where I want and not supporting Amazon. I do think they could spruce up their website a little... but it's not that important.

eBooks.title: Do not use this website
eBooks.body: Do not use this website. The ebooks you download have to be used with "Adobe Digital Edition," which requires you to make an Adobe membership and then "authorize" the program with your membership on your computer just to open any of the books you attempt to download. DRM will not allow you to simply download a book and open it like a PDF. However, the real problem is that MY BOOK WOULDN'T OPEN! I downloaded the book and tried to open it with my authorized Digital Editions, and it would simply say "Errors were encountered in this item." I searched online for solutions, and only found that - yup - sometimes it just doesn't work! So I reached out to ebooks.com to ask for a refund, and was told they'd be happy to give me credit or an actual refund, but that they'd first like the specific error I received. By this point I had uninstalled Digital Editions (didn't need a useless program around), so I had to go back and reinstall it. Only now, Digital Editions wouldn't authorize under my adobe account! I told them this, and sent them a screenshot showing this new error, again asking for my refund. They replied back with a link telling me what to do to solve this new, 2nd issue, then insisted my problem was resolved and closed my help ticket. Um, NO! I was able to get Digital Editions to authorize again, but it STILL WON'T OPEN MY BOOK! My original problem - the thing I contacted them about - has been completely ignored. It has now been several days, and several emails later and they are simply ignoring me. Avoid ebooks.com at all costs - do not buy anything from them, as not only is the basic process a nightmare, but if something doesn't work and you insist on a refund, they will just start to ignore you.

It took me around an hour on Linux to break through the DRM just so that I can have a regular ePub that I can copy to any devices without having to have Adobe Digital Editions or other proprietary software installed.The system doesn't serve its purpose of preventing theft since now I could (not that I will) upload the ePub for anybody in the world to read free of charge. After making a purchase, the reader is given two options to read the book - a download link, and an in-browser pop-up window. From what i can tell, the download link is completely broken. They make it very clear that they want you to download their reader app before you download the book, and while the book is labeled ".ePub" on the site, the file you actually get is just garbled junk. Completely unusable.The in-browser pop-up window works, but only that. The software legit looks like it's from around 1995, and the loading of pages can be very slow (sometimes they don't load at all). The scrolling bar is very imprecise, and the extra features (such as the "search this book" function) also only work when they want to. You can make it work if you really need it, but there are many better options out there aside from this relic of a site.

I myself, due to stupidity, have had my account hacked, back before any steam authenticator was setup and therefore can say that it has never been an issue since - my account was returned and restored with the help of customer support.There is no wonder Steam is the most popular gaming platform on PC due to having the biggest availability of games out of all gaming platforms. The store front is quite simple to use/find the games you love as well as the discovery queue to quickly browse games that are recommended to your gaming tastes.Can not recommend anything other for those wanting to start out on PC Gaming.

Steam.title: Steam is the platform that redefined PC…
Steam.body: Steam is the platform that redefined PC gaming. Features like Steam Sales, Steam Cloud, automatic updates, the ability to redownload at any time, and integrated chat features made Steam so useful that many people are willing to forego the freedom of DRM-free games in order to have the convenience that Steam gives. Steam.title: Customer Service? Where?
Steam.body: I've used their platform and bought several games that are great sometimes and mediocre other times. However, with a recent purchase I found after my initial hours of spotty game time, it quit running on my PC. After reading through the intent of their returns and refunds policy, I felt a refund in this situation was appropriate. Yet when I make a customer service refund request, I never feel like my problems are answered or reviewed by an actual person. Just automated feeling answers that don't look at your explanations and intent of the return. If you've played more than 2 hours and had the game more than 2 weeks, you're out of luck no matter the reason.Over all, I'd like to know my explanation were read. Maybe this is how it will always be, but in this technology age I think companies should be able to keep up with customers and help come to a solution to keep them happy and wanting to come back for more.In the future I'll have to look somewhere else for my gaming wants and I recommend you do the same. Because the prices aren't worth the risk of spotty or no gameplay.

Steam.title: THE BEST!
Steam.body: Best customer service and best platform to purchase video games, hands down. Do not believe the negative reviews! If the issue is related to Steam, they always resolve it. And then, how one can get their account stolen with Steam Guard protection and two-factor authentication active is honestly beyond me!!! Personally, I have 15 years of service, almost 2000 video games, and 2 Steam Decks, and on those rare occasions when I had problems, customer service was prompt in resolving them, sometimes even at their own expense (for example: recently, they sent me brand new chargers, a case, and a screen cleaning cloth for the Steam Deck, free of charge, which I had mistakenly sent to them with the device for RMA, and which had gotten lost. It was my fault!). The only thing I can say is that, over these years, I have always felt extremely satisfied with the treatment I have received. Thank you for your work!

Steam.title: Steam Promoting Racial Advertising
Steam.body: I am writing regarding Steam's handling of a recent inquiry I made about their promotional strategies, particularly the emphasis on 'Black Gaming of the Month'. My experience with their customer service has raised serious concerns about their transparency and potential racial bias in their advertising choices.I initially contacted Steam to express my concerns over their seemingly exclusive focus on games related to Black history, while seemingly neglecting the contributions and narratives of other racial and cultural groups within the gaming community. This approach appeared to contradict the principles of diversity and inclusivity, which are vital in the gaming industry.However, my attempt to engage with Steam on this matter was met with a lack of substantive response. Instead of addressing my concerns directly, Steam suggested that I use their public forums to discuss this issue, a recommendation that I found inappropriate for an internal policy-related matter. Further efforts to seek clarification and a formal response from Steam were abruptly halted when they closed my support topic, without providing any satisfactory explanation or resolution. A practice they never do under other topic to the support group.This action, and the lack of transparent communication from Steam, has led me to believe that there might be an underlying unwillingness to acknowledge or address potential biases in their promotional strategies. The closure of the support topic, particularly without a proper resolution or acknowledgment of the issue raised, suggests a concerning level of disregard for customer feedback, especially on matters as significant as racial representation and inclusivity.I wanted to highlight Steam's apparent lack of transparency and possible racial bias in their promotional choices. It is crucial for consumers and the wider public to be aware of how companies handle sensitive issues related to racial representation and customer feedback.I hope that Steam reevaluates their communication and promotional strategies, ensuring they align with the values of inclusivity and diversity, and that they maintain a transparent and responsive dialogue with their customer base.

Steam.title: Awful
Steam.body: Very, very awful Steam Support and Moderation Staff.I've been a victim of targeted bullying and antagonizing behavior committed by a string of users from within the Steam Forum itself. I've had my public game reviews bombarded and mocked multiple times. I have tried to play nice for the first couple months and have made many reports.My reports have been ignored, brushed under the rug and every disciplinary action was taken out on me. I was banned 4 times from the steam forums. Understandably, my behavior has been unacceptable per time coming back from the bannings.However, that doesn't devalue the fact that EVERY single user is to be beholden under the rules of the Steam Forum and Community Guidelines. Why is it, am I the only one punished when there had been insurmountable evidence that shows other users picking at, belittling, berating, harassing, stalking and provoking me.Instead, my posts are removed and I'm painted as the problematic scapegoat in the community. Moderators and Steam Support have given me the cold shoulder, but they're right on me in seconds to issue bans and warnings.How is any of this fair? What is it telling when your support staff do not hold a neutral judgment on anything that happens in the community? That by not dealing with the troublesome users, you are rewarding and enabling them to continue to do as they like by having them jump on people they don't like when they post topics and threads of discussion in the forums.Moreso, allowing them to get away with instigating issues with other users who have otherwise contributed to the Steam Platform with game reviews.Again, how is any of this fair to punish and shelve one user when multiple users have committed similar faults? It isn't and I think the whole moderation staff need to undergo sensitivity training and refine their judgmental skills or just be let go entirely to find newer people who can do a fairer job that they couldn't.

Steam.title: Refund Issues, Appalling Customer Support
Steam.body: Like other recent reviewers I have experienced poor customer service from Steam. I bought a DLC for a game I had previously bought but uninstalled. That meant when I downloaded the DLC I had to re-install the main game. This time when I played the main game it was so buggy that I could hardly progress my character because the game kept crashing. I couldn't access the DLC content because that relied on my character having reached a high level. Steam wouldn't refund the cost of the DLC because they claimed I had played the DLC for more than two hours - they had metered my playtime of the main game instead of playtime of the DLC which I never managed to experience. I now have a buggy version of the main game which is now virtually unplayable and wasn't bugged when I played the old version two years ago. The game developers have told me they can't fix (repair) the bugs so I am left with a faulty product which breaches my rights as a consumer. There is no direct email address for Steam Support and no option to place a general complaint about their poor support. I am now faced with shelling out for recorded delivery to send a formal complaint by surface mail to Steam's head office in my country. I'm not going to buy games from them in the future!

Steam.title: Steam tries to force people to quit Win 7, do not obey if you have a backbone

Over time got used to it.Now in april 2023 Valve (steam) announced they are going to shut off their platform to users of Windows 7 at the end of this year, so from 2024 on we cannot use any games we spent money on, in good faith. I am not bowing to Steam's demands what OS I should be using to stay in touch with my purchases.Wait. This whole story reminds us that we don't own games here, we seem to 'rent' them until the platform finds a reason to lock them away from us if we don't obey.They could just leave a Steam client running especially for Win7 like forever, no? Win7 is 64bit just like Win10 (just better), so the excuse is rather weak, stating some Chrome browser (which I never use) can't run any longer on Win7, so bye-bye to you all.I advise everybody no longer to buy games on Steam and look for a DRM-free place, like GOG is. Unfortunately some games are Steam-exclusively "sold" (rented), in this case, pirated versions may be the last option - hey, you paid for them already, that is the best excuse ever to get yourself a copy which will run regardless.After all, I was not so wrong when I had my reservations about Steam back in the days...

Steam.title: Atrocious customer service
Steam.body: I can no longer access my account and have lost hundreds of pounds worth of games, after having password issues.  Because I no longer have voucher codes from many years ago (approximately 2018), or my old bank card details (from 2019), I cannot receive any help from customer support.  Instead, they seem to keep adding in a prompt that I should be the original owner of the account in order to regain access...  I am.  Their customer service options for being locked out of an account are, frankly, laughable.  Looking at the reviews on this page, others seem to have had the same problem. Steam.title: Steam:  Taking the lead from Revenge Porn Sites
Steam.body: In the last few days, Amazon Gaming Services falsely banned tens of thousands of accounts for being bots, causing them to be flagged on Steam as having a ban on their account.  Most of the banned accounts were simply inactive:  people who had tried out a free to play game called "Lost Ark", played a few hours and then lost interest.Most of those banned, including myself, don't care about not being able to play Lost Ark.  The problem is that the ban is registered on their Steam Account, affecting their reputation and impacting on their ability to play other games.  One example is Rust, which blocks users who have had a ban applied to their account in the last 180 days.  There are also other games that check for accounts for bans for the purpose of applying trust ratings to players.  When the players are rated as "un-trusted" it leads to them being excluded by other players.While I completely support banning botters, cheats and disruptive players, I don't agree that it is ok to misrepresent over 10,000 players as cheaters, simply because they tried out a free to play game six months ago and didn't continue playing. Steam designed, implemented and own the platform on which this is happening.  Even though Amazon Gaming Services have indicated the mass banning was a mistake on their part, Steam have done absolutely nothing for the players that still are flagged as banned on Steam as a result.  Steam are basically acting in the same way a revenge porn site:  creating the means and the medium for publishers to post harmful and inaccurate information, but taking no responsibility and saying it's not their fault and doing nothing to remove the harmful content they have facilitated.

Steam.title: First, they took my money - Then locked my accounts
Steam.body: This is the worst company I have ever had to deal with by a long shot!==================================================SHORT STORY:Bought 2 games on 2 of my Steam accounts.Then Steam restricted both my accounts, rendering them basically useless.Steam fails to provide me with a valid reason WHY they did this.All they say is that they want me to provide my 25 year old physcal copy of my Half-Life 1 key from 1998.I didn't keep the original CD + key anymore after registering it with Steam in 2003, as both CD and key were rendered useless by registering it on Steam.Now my money is gone.I have 2 useless Steam accounts.Steam stole both my money and account.They completely refuse to coorporate with me in this issue.==================================================LONG STORY:Last week my wife and I decided to buy a new game to play together. I bought the game 2 times on both my accounts.Perfect - I thought!One day later I open Steam and get an alert message:----------------------------------------> This account may have been accessed by someone else.> Steam Support suspects your account may have been accessed by someone else. We are temporarily restricting modifications to this account as a security precaution. Please contact Steam Support so we can assist you.> > This account will have restricted functionality until the owner has regained access.> Purchasing, gifting, trading, cd-key activation, playing online on VAC enabled game servers, and Steam Community access have been disabled.----------------------------------------That this happened on BOTH my accounts!I quickly contacted the Steam support and got the following reply:----------------------------------------> In order to recover this account, we must verify your ownership of the original CD Key that was used to create this Steam account.----------------------------------------I am one of the oldest customers this company has. I created my Steam account in 2003 when Counter-Strike 1.6 was first made available. To register it, Half-Life 1 keys from 1998 were required.This means:- The CD key was from 1998 => 25 years ago.- The CD key was registered 20 years ago with SteamBoth CD and key were then absolutely useless/worthless and not required anymore for any reason whatsoever. The key could not be registered with another Steam account and the game could only be downloaded via Steam. Why should I keep 2 useless and worthless pieces of plastic/paper for another 20 years?Steam doesn't care at all that everything ever associated with the account (e-mail addresses, payments etc.) has my name on it. They wouldn't even accept my ID/passport as proof. I proactively suggested alternative means of proof, but they simply ignored it.The Steam support keeps on repeating that the one and only possibility for me to have my account recovered is to provide this specific (CD key from 1998) proof.This whole issue is absolutely absurd on so many levels and probably also illegal!It was easier to get a copy of my birth certificate in Germany than to recover my Steam account... Just think about that...CONCLUSION:They take my money for the games, then they restrict my account and leave me hanging.Great job, Steam...P.S.:I think that the customer support system is completely run my AI, because- my questions are not getting answered,- the responses I get are always the same text blocks and- I only can give 2 answers inside the ticket until they just close it (because - you know - I failed to comply with their ultimatum about the 25 year old CD key).

I have tried 4 different methods and spent a fraction of the hours playing to try and repair the files, or research how to back them up.Most fingers point to steams abysmal cloud storage system for their issues and have found fixes, but none of them have worked in my situation, so now I’ve spent hours trying to contact them or get a refund. They are impossible to contact, and try to point the finger at square Enix, even though it’s clearly their file storage system failing, and when I request a refund, it’s promptly refused without human review because I have played over 2 hours.My game is unplayable at this point, because who wants to play another 18 hours over to have to potentially restart, and to even test whether it will even save, I would have to run through the whole beginning sequence and waste my time if it doesn’t.So beyond frustrated with all my time wasted.Edit: Square enix itself got back to me almost immediately to my complete and utter disbelief. They were quick to help, and provided a list of file locations to check and relay the information back to them so they could diagnose and fix my issue. This unfortunately wasn’t my first rodeo with Steam, so I thanked Square Enix and let them know I would simply repurchase CC on the Switch as I’ve decided to leave steam permanently. The fact that a company who’s reputation is that large took ample time to reply multiple times and fast made it clear that I no longer wish to support steam, and will happily spend that money to support a company that actually cares.

This looks like a first person shooter game in which a terrorist kills Israeli soldiers while yelling "Allah akbar." The game's own web site (Trustpilot does not allow links but you can see yourself) advocates the destruction of Israel with the words "From the river to the sea," which meets the definition of anti-Semitic.The IHRC definition of anti-Semitism is not disagreement with the policies of Israel, but rather denial of Israel's right to exist. While Steam /Valve Corporation certainly have the First Amendment right to sell a game of this nature, others have the First Amendment right to complain about it.The trailer (on Steam's web site) includes the terrorist feeding an Israeli soldier to a shark, killing another one with a chain saw, execution-style shooting of a downed Israeli, and a suicide bombing. (The game does not, however, feature violence against Israeli civilians.)In addition, some of the reviews of the game contain openly anti-Semitic content like "Let me tell you that as much as the next sane and noble guy I hate the international banker and media manipulating tribe," "Hell yeah, I love anti-semitism too," and "Anyone mad over the publishing of this game is just a victim of the propaganda perpetuated by the small hat people." Steam.title: Abysmal “Customer Service”
Steam.body: Admittedly, Steam customer service is appalling. Let us look at Valve/Steam’s business model. We have an online merchant (storefront) selling and streaming games on their ‘distribution’ platform. The breadth and depth of their customer and technical support does not extend beyond referring customers to the software developer or other Steam customers (forum).  Very shrewd business operation would you agree? This allows Valve/Steam to maintain low overhead while assuming no responsibility for post-sales support. In effect, Valve/Steam is a third-party company that sells software as-is and processes credit card transactions. Billing is efficient and instantaneous while refunds are equivalent to a rigged card game where the dealer always prevails.  In addition, responses are canned and fail to address the specific issue. For example, customer purchased Street Fighter V. Game did not have sound when connected to a large screen HDTV. Other games tested on Valve/Steam distribution platform functioned normally. In fact, Street Fighter IV functions as designed. Customer reached out to Steam and received a canned response to contact Capcom. Contacted Capcom and received no response. Posted the issue in the Steam forums and received no response.  Frustrated, contacted Steam to request a refund and was immediately denied. Not a word regarding my technical issue, only referring to the time-usage policy. The more humorous aspect of this is the rabid responses received when posting this experience within the Steam forum. One would suspect that the Steam protectors were dispatched in full force to stifle any critics of this glorified software vender. Not withstanding the sunk cost, it was entertaining to see the myriad responses when “charge back” was voiced.  Couldn’t obtain a single response initially but the careful use of these two blasphemous words garnered immediate attention. Why? Admittedly, the hard-hitting responses were expected as a charge back is the only way the customer can retain some type of control of his/her financial transaction (investment). With a claimed customer base of 27M users, we are not dealing with Ph.D.’s. In the present case, outside of the repeated mimicking of the return policy, there was absolutely no comprehension of the issue, time wasted, and money lost.  The highlight of the forum exchange was a satirical response from a dimwit posting a link to an obscure third-party website that purported to address the glitch with SFV.  Although, Valve/Steam, Capcom, and the Forum soldiers were unable/unwilling to provide any initial assistance, customers are expected to be aware of an obscure website. Shame on the customer for failing to find one website out of the 1.2B websites on the Internet! The key takeaways from this frustrating and oddly entertaining experience are numerous. Purchase software at your own risk, software is sold ‘as is’, return policy supersedes all situations, Steam provides no technical support, technical support is the responsibility of the software developer, and the software developer has no obligation to provide technical support. In other words, do not waste your time trying to engage customer service, software developer, or the kids in the forum. Request a refund immediately and move on. Valve/Steam is NOT in the business of issuing returns and thus, do not allow yourself to be bullied. The intent of Valve/Steam is to evade the customer so that he/she writes-off their losses and moves on. Most importantly, as Kryptonite weakens Superman, the charge-back weakens Steam. Do not be afraid to use this and be prepared to engage the Steam mob if mentioning this in the forums (sandbox).  From a consumer protection perspective, it is believed that Valve/Steam does have a level of responsibility to address/resolve customer concerns. The link between Valve/Steam and the developer is intentionally ambiguous. Neither want to increase headcount and manage post-sales support as it does not provide the short-term revenue as does processing credit card transactions. This is one of the reasons why pirating of software persists. Why spend/lose $40 on SFV and deal with these headaches when it can be obtained for free? Based on the sheer volume of complaints, the consumer must leverage the charge-back process when appropriate and until Valve/Steam makes the necessary improvements. Steam.title: With a little extra love, Steam would be absolutely amazing!
Steam.body: I have been using Steam for about 15 months now and have accumulated almost 100 games in that time. Take the bad reviews on here with a grain of salt as most of the complaints that I read seem to be from user error. PROS: 1. Steam have a great "No questions asked" refund system that if you buy a game and don't like it, you can get the full refund as long as you haven't played the game for more than 2 hours. This has saved me a lot of money in the past and I can purchase any game in confidence knowing that if it doesn't hit my happy button, I can simply get a refund. The process for this is super quick too (as in under 20 mins), using their online tool directly through the platform.  2. The new interface as it is more visual and engaging. 3. I have a tower at home and a laptop for when I am on the go and I can stream through either device and the saves are automatic! 4. Wishlist the games that you like, Steam will always flick you a notification when they go on sale. It's a great way to save money and enjoy more of the games that you love. CONS (mainly about the interface): 1. This is not really Steam's fault (although they could strike up a deal with the developers) but some games force you to sign up to another platform (like Origin for Star Wars Fallen Order) in order to play. While the game saves and appears in steam, every time I want to play that game, I have to open up Origin and play it through there. Once you accumulate enough games, you end up having too many different platforms open all at once just to play your favourite games. Steam should try to work with the developers so that you can open the game up directly through Steam. Steam could show the developers logo, or maybe ask the gamer for permission, or show a banner that says that the game is made by the developer each time you play the game, something to promote the developer but allowing the game to launch through steam would be way better than opening multiple other programs just to play the games. I buy the games through Steam, so I should be able to play the games through Steam. I shouldn't have to open/download and sign up to other platforms to play it (that's like ordering food from MacDonalds but having to pick it up at Hungry Jacks). 2. Sometimes during searches in the store page, clicking on a game, checking it out, and then deciding to return back to the store page, pressing the back button takes me back to the beginning of the store page. This means that I have to scroll allllllll the way back down to where I was to continue shopping. This is tedious and annoying and it would be great for Steam to remember where I last was browsing and so when I go back to the store page, it takes me right back to where I was. 3. There is no option to open up a game on the store page in a new window. Very frustrating for people that like organisation. When I get onto the store page and start scrolling down, it would be great to highlight/select/open up all the games that catch my eye and then go through them all, one by one, to decide which ones I want to "Wishlist," which ones that I want to buy and which ones I don't want. Having to open one game at a time and then after my decision of that game, I have to return back to the store page, only to be reloaded and sent to the very top of the page. This means that I have to scroll alllll the way down again to where I was last in order to try and refind my place, and this is annoying and a waste of time!  4. Have more than 4 pictures per game on the store page, or maybe replace the images with actual gameplay. I am a visual person who likes to see what the gameplay looks like. Most of the time when I see a game that I like, I click on it and the first thing I am shown is the game trailer, understandably. Usually, most trailers don't show a lot of actual gameplay. This means that I end up leaving Steam and jumping onto YouTube to find some actual gameplay. This is time consuming, tedious and probably is a loss of sales on your end. Having instant gameplay appear when I hover my mouse over a potential game would definitely entice me to want to see more, which could lead to more sales for you. 5. You should come up with your own Humble Bundle style monthly subscription program where subscribers can pay a couple of bucks a month and get a few games as a bundle. I sign up to Humble Bundle for their monthly games and always end up loading them into steam anyway. Your marketing team should be way ahead of the game here dominating this space since all the games purchased through Humble, all get loaded onto your platform anyway. I would support it. 6. Your customer service is not great, the reviewers are clear about this. Perhaps a little extra training or if you were to pull off step number 5 above, you could use that money to invest into more customer service staff tuning these irritate reviews into positive ones. This and a few more ideas I have up my sleeve could see you dominating this space within the next 12-24 months, easily. Naturally, these are suggestions from my personal opinion and so I don't expect miracles (as based on the negative reviews on here, you have enough #!@$% to deal with, if you are even dealing with them), so I won't hold my breath for your response but when you next decide to throw us an update, these changes would be a lovely addition. Think about it.  Thanks and keep up the pretty good 'but needs attention' work!

Steam.title: Long time victim.
Steam.body: I'm writing this after having used Steam for roughly 10 years, and while it's not entirely useless there are better competitors on the market now vs when I first joined. I wanted to give 1 star as the cons of Steam is that inconvenient to me, but I'm giving them 2 because I do enjoy the community and workshops for games that support it. So what makes it so bad in my opinion? The horrendous customer service and how stupidly difficult it is to get any actual help, the system they use makes it hard to find answers to even basic questions but also makes it nearly impossible to intuitively send a help ticket-- which in 2020 is something you expect from even the lowest budget sites and service, let alone a giant like Steam. Frequent errors while purchasing games, the client crashing or just processing for an eternity before it failing-- getting an error message that you've attempted to buy too many games in the last few hours (when you've had 2 unsuccessful attempts) and getting a time out. They don't specify how many games to get a time out or how long it lasts, I've heard 10 games and 1 hour-- but gotten time outs with as little as 2 and for longer than 1 hour. Them blaming it on services like PayPal when PayPal hasn't been loaded at all and no money has been withdrawn by them, etc. No support when there is something wrong with a game or a company ripped you off, having to send evidence is expected-- but you can't actually add anything to the message so how exactly are you supposed to do that (messaging them to ask how leads nowhere naturally)? The positives are that with so many users there are a lot of people creating things for the workshops which is nice, and there are some good sales and indie games. When it works it works pretty well too, but really that's nothing to brag about as that's what it's supposed to do. I'd recommend finding somewhere else to buy games if you can, for us who already have a large library of games we're stuck but for new customers-- run.

Steam.title: Care with refund policy
Steam.body: Take care with the supposed Steam 2 hour play time refund policy. Many Steam games come with their own launcher/update software. Even if this software is running only in order to download additional content it will count as play time. So as was the case with Elder Scrolls Online the game downloaded from Steam, the launcher was started and ran for several hours updating and patching the game. The game then crashed on every start. But even though there had been zero play time Steam would not refund an unplayable game as they system showed 4 hours of play time. Steam need to develop a process by which they can see play time rather than 3rd party launcher run time, otherwise the refund policy is potentially meaningless

Steam.title: So a few days ago I tried to purchase a…
Steam.body: So a few days ago I tried to purchase a bundle before the fall sale ended, but ran into issues as I could not get the bundle to add to my cart it would only offer the purchase as a gift option.  I was trying to buy the counterstrike bundle but it would not add as I already have the free version of csgo in my library. At first I thought this was some sort of glitch on my mobile app so I restarted the app still nothing I attempted to figure out how to remove the free version as I thought maybe that was the issue but was unable to figure it out how to on the app. I've had demos of other titles before or other free versions and have not needed to remove them in order to upgrade to the full game or purchase the full game so naturally being that these are valve products  and steam is a valve owned company youd expect them to have it worked out so people don't run into these  issues, and to ice the cake without removing the free version I can add csgo to my cart and proceed to check out without receiving the product already owned or in library notification on the cart screen. Yet when I try to add the bundle i can't because it claims csgo is in my library. I mean yes I could have just bought the game by itself as it would add to the cart but when csgo was on sale for $8.47 and the bundle of all 3 counterstrike games was on sale for $8.29 it seems kind of illogical to pay more for less. All this said I sent in a ticket sharing my frustration and questioning how this issue was occurring well expressing my confusion that it will let me add the game but not the bundle,  and after waiting a day and a half received responce that basically says sorry there's nothing we can do for you, more a less it's not in steams policy to offer customers anything for having a bad experience with there service followed by the instructions on how to remove the free game from my library and the recommendation that I put the game on my wishlist and wait and see if it goes on sale followed by a shameless plug for there weekly sales and daily specials. Here's a company that makes billions in revenue annually from people like myself who regularly spend on games, and then as a customer you reach out in frustration over a bad experience caused by issues with their store and they respond with sorry for the inconvenience,  its not our policy to offer items at discounts before or after sales, so if you want the game your going to have to buy it at full price or wait, but in the mean time be sure to check our specials section for more great deals.... Great policy tell an upset customer who spends money every week on products that the only help you can provide is the advise to look at the other products that can be bought... Steam.title: Steam Revoked Legitimate Game Key
Steam.body: A steam key for the PC game Call of Cthulhu was placed on sale in the Humble Store, I purchased it, and the key was sent to me and redeemed.  I put three hours into the game.  Humble later claimed they priced it incorrectly, refunded the amount, and revoked the key.  Steam removed it from my account.  The sale price should be honored for those who purchased a copy while it was active.The notice I received from Steam was a lie:"A Steam Product code you activated has been removed from your account.Nov 21   Call of Cthulhu®Your recent Product code activation has been revoked due to a problem processing payment for this item. The games associated with this product code can no longer be played as a result. This could be due a problem with the payment methods you used to acquire this item from a third-party seller; or a problem with how the third-party seller acquired the Product code. Please contact the seller you acquired the Product code from for assistance.If you would like to purchase the item, please visit the Steam Store. Otherwise you may choose to delete the local content associated with these games."The key was legitimate and purchased from a "legitimate" (if apparently not trustworthy) retailer, the transaction was completed and I have an electronic paper trail to prove it, the retailer screwed up and revoked the key.  Whether this was driven by Steam, Humble Bundle, or the publishers, the practice was wholly unacceptable and a breach of consumer trust.  Changing the price is fine - that's their right, but revoking transactions already completed under the sale price should not have been done.

Steam.title: Steam Guard is flawed!
Steam.body: Update:Steam has reinstated my account and stated any future charge backs could result in a permanent ban. No info on 2FA issues or looking into it and no info on banning the account where the money was sent. Obviously, the seller account that received my money is at least complicit in fraud, if not the fraudster themself. I have since removed all payment methods from my Steam account and intend to only use Steam gift cards as an extra layer of security. I would highly suggest at a bare minimum not allowing auto payments from Steam through PayPal or storing bank information on your Steam account.Origin review:I got hacked due to malware. 8 accounts were having multiple access attempts from across the globe (China, Germany, UK, Vietnam, etc). These accounts were Steam, Amazon, Coinbase, Binance, PayPal, Robinhood, Meta, and Gmail. All but Steam blocked access with Two Factor Authentication, Steam's 2FA didn't even register. $200 charged and sent through their Community Market to another user. I started a support ticket and it was closed without response. I then contacted PayPal and they just about immediately issued my charge back. Now Steam has banned me for issuing a charge back and blames me for not stopping the malware. The malware was caught with live protection, but it took about an hour. I lost $200 in about 5 minutes, though it has been returned. With some searching, it seems I am far from the only one to have their Steam Guard (2FA) bypassed and losing items or money.

Steam.title: Steam is choosing to censor users…
Steam.body: Steam is choosing to censor user reviews to appease large corporations who do anti-consumer things. When corporations/publishers/developers participate in anti-consumer behavior, then one avenue users have to warn others of such anti-consumer behavior is to leave reviews.When consumers leave reviews about anti-consumer behavior, this is seen by the corporations who sell their products on steam as unwanted review fluctuations. Steam labels them "off-topic" "review bombs".The corporations who sell their products on the steam platform, have pressured steam into developing a special review system that detects unusual fluctuations in review scores due to companies doing scummy things, and hide the fluctuation. It's so hard for these companies to not do anti-consumer things that it's easier to hide the evidence than change their business practices.While there is an opt out, these companies can bank on the fact that the bulk of users will not know this censoring system is in place, or that there is the option to turn it off in the settings. Apathy will allow companies to get away with anti-consumer practices with reduced repercussions. A major issue with this is that the definition of off-topic is not well defined, Valve can not be depended upon to be transparent, or communicative, and the whole system is open to abuse. Furthermore it opens the door to further censorship in future.Valve is selling out to the corporations, and giving them increased ability to abuse steam customers, through taking away those customer's voices.

Steam.title: Pros & Cons
Steam.body: I am troubled about how many stars i should give so i put the average. However i must note that i am an active player and will continoue using the platform.Pros- Endless game database.- Steam sales resulting in extremely low prices.- Steam keys being sold from 3rd party websites as bundles or single titles so you can get even better value for money.- Steam keys can be gifted to friends directly.- Game reviews from actual players.- Social features incl. friend list & chat, news, groups, marketplace. I had some issues finding friends using common nicknames, but unfortunately steam will not let you use their account name.- Direct player invite for multiplayer/coop games etc. without depending on the actual game's multiplayer interface. For example when playing online games that require certain ports that your firewall or router has closed for any reason, you can result in losing hours trying to connect through the game client, while through steam overlay you can connect directly.- Workshop for finding user or official made content.Cons- Customer support; as you will notice from most reviews it can vary from extremely terrible to very helpful. I think the reason for this is purely a matter of people working in customer support. I noticed that the same issue not handled well or even rejected from one person was resolved from another after i insisted. So my advise is never give up even if you are totally frustrated from the replies you receive.- Not all games are published through steam (e.g. new EA games are only found in their platform).- Many old games are not well ported in steam and various new games have serious bugs, but developer support stops early. I strongly recommend reading the user comments before buying anything at all. You should realise that other users' opinions or issues may not be the case with you and should always check the overall picture instead of isolated good or bad reviews.- Market monopoly is never good for developers or players.

Steam.title: Mostly fantastic
Steam.body: I've been on Steam for about ten and a half years now and have hardly had a problem. The software has always worked fine for me, it is very easy to install and uninstall games and the store has never given me any issues.At first I was apprehensive due to having less ownership of the game than if I owned a physical copy. But when Civilization 5 required Steam I decided to give it a go.Now I cannot imagine having to go back to DVD copies of games, the hassle of finding the DVD I need when I want to play and manual patching. Although there are a few things I'd change about Steam which I'll get to below, something far worse could have taken Steam's place in terms of DRM. Steam can be launched in offline mode and games played offline. The developers can choose to allow games bought on Steam to be launched without the Steam client being open.As well as partly being DRM, Steam has a lot of features which make my life as a gamer a lot easier. Most games support Steam cloud, backing up save files so you don't lose them if you forget to back up when changing computer. Game files can be backed up to an external hard drive to make restoring them a lot quicker than redownloading them. Compared to most competitors such as Origin, Epic Games and Ubisoft Connect, Steam has the most features and the least annoying DRM.There are a couple of things I would change about Steam. I'd prefer it to be totally DRM free like GOG. Although it is great that indie developers are given a chance, Steam make it a bit too easy to publish and there are lots of very low quality games to sift through. You're forced to always be updated to the latest version of a game. I'd prefer if I could pause updates or easily roll back if an update gives me an issue or is not compatible with my save file.I notice a few reviews here saying that Steam is expensive. It is if you buy most of your games full price from the Store. I recommend getting the majority of your games through Humble Bundle and other bundle sites like Fanatical and Indie Gala as well as in Steam sales. The Christmas and Summer sales are best. Getting the bulk of your games through bundles and in sales actually makes Steam an extremely cost effective way to build a library of games.

Steam.title: PURCHASE ANYTHING FROM STEAM AT YOUR OWN PERIL
Steam.body: GETS 1 STAR AS ZERO ISNT POSSIBLEBE WARNED - STEAM's return/refund policy is basically like buying a movie, getting it home, watching it but it cuts out halfway through, and when you try to take it back for an exchange you're told "You should have known it was defective. You watched the first half so you don't qualify for any compensation".Erm - Are you serious? Sadly yes I am.I purchased Final Fantasy VIII remastered, a game that takes a minimum of 30 - 35 hours to complete even just for the trophy list, but most people will take 100+ hours as its massively open world.My purchase repeatedly crashed at the Fisherman's Harbour location after 90 hours play (got to fight off the Lockdown Blues somehow). It kept crashing even after dozens of tries at fixes with various settings (including running as admin), and always at exactly the same place. Eventually I gave up.I contacted steam, requesting a credit (not refund) against another purchase as their game is not playable - AND WAS REFUSED?!?Why? Because I had played the game for more than 2 hours. 2 HOURS DOESNT GET YOU PAST THE FIRST MISSION YOU ID**TS!!!!!!!!So if any game you purchase crashes after 2 hours, its apparently not their fault, its yours for not playing the game at light speed to get to the Exception notice/glitch/Crash that might be dozens of hours into a game.Oh yes - and if it is a Steam third party client as with Final Fantasy creators Square Enix, that too is not Steams fault, even though you downloaded the game from Steam. So basically STEAM takes the money, but any issues are someone else's problem.I don't care about the money (it's £7.99). It's about good customer service, holding your hands up and taking responsibility for a product you sell, and for treating your customers with a modicum of common decency.Concepts totally alien to the soulless robots working at STEAM.My advice is that if a game crashes before the 2 hour cut off, DO NOT PLAY FURTHER. Contact STEAM immediately.And if its after 2 hours? Just give up - they don't care and will only send you an automatic response that says:-"We are unable to refund this purchase to your Steam Wallet at this time. Your playtime of an included product exceeds 2 hours (our refund policy maximum)."Says it all really.Rant over, SoapBox away.

However, when I selected the option to 'ask a question,' I was able to get my refund request reviewed by a Steam technician.   They understood the situation and were able to refund the purchase to 'steam wallet' (store credit), which is an outcome I can be happy with.   Downsides: Refund requests automatically declined with >2 hours play time due to policy.   Upsides: There is some wiggle room, especially if you have not abused the refund system. Steam.title: Good sales, Bad support, Some glitches, Bad 2FA
Steam.body: Has good sales. App is well organized, but can be glitchy. Auto-run can be disabled (recommended). Supports playing with friends. Possibly the worst aspect of the design is that 2-factor authorization is only through a proprietary app, so you have to add a whole separate app to your phone in order to use app-based 2FA. A whole authorization app on your phone just for Steam. Support from the store is useless. For example, Steam Controller on sale. I want two but can put only 1 in my cart so I write them a quick message to check if this is WAI. I watch for a reply. Day 3: controller is out of stock, so I update my ticket with a request for a rain check. Day 4: they finally reply with the message: controller out of stock; Only able to add 1 to cart at a time; Also this is technical support. Wow, they think I hadn't noticed it was out of stock? I reply with a second request for a rain check, and suggest they add a sales support contact to their website. Day 6: They reply saying the controller has no definite plans for production in the immediate future. They do not offer me any alternate promotions or give-aways as compensation for me missing out due to their very tardy reply, and due to their broken/poorly designed shopping cart which cannot ship two items to the same address at once (or their badly configured item pricing versus shipping, if they were using the shipping to subsidize the price and that's why they didn't want to ship 2 to the same address, which shouldn't cost twice as much). Support tickets, I should add, can be made by choosing from a pre-set list of games and such very specific topics. There are not general topics, and barely any "other" type options. No "other" option is a beginning topic, sales questions don't relate to "I need sales (nontechnical) support making a purchase", and there's no "something else" option under "Purchases".

Steam.title: Haters gonna hate
Steam.body: You know, it didn't surprise me one bit when I saw all the negative reviews of Steam.  We gamers are some passionate, opinionated people, man, and Steam is one of those big-ass companies we love to hate.  But if I'm honest, I have never had a single problem with Steam since about 2006, when they refused to merge my two accounts -- ultimately their right, I suppose, but their security system back then used to be clunky af and their customer service department used to be a whole separate entity that made it really difficult to get anything resolved.  They are much more normalized now.  And since that one hiccup, I gotta tell ya, I've never had a problem.  They refund crap games every time I ask with no hassle, they deliver gifts immediately, they have a righteous selection of big dev and indie games, and I've never had technical problems with Steam itself (sure some buggy "forever in Alpha" games crash, but that's not Steam, that's a Buyer Beware situation with the game devs). Tl;dr, yeah Steam has become the easy target to hate, but I use them exclusively for all my gaming except Riot and Blizzard games and have literally zero complaints.

Steam.title: I'm not really a fan of steam, but
Steam.body: I'm not a fan of the steam-flavored monopoly, but I haven't had problems with crashing like others have. As a user interface designer, I find their layout/color options are abysmal, (I can *never* see the search box on my monitor, for example), and like others I find their speed to update the interface to be ridiculously slow (but a little bit faster/better lately)Also, there are errors that have been around for years and haven't gotten fixed.I have sent in a few ideas with "please don't reply to me, just forward this" and one of them got implemented not much later. I've sent in a few help requests and gotten mostly canned answers, but with a little work, the issues were resolved satisfactorily. (Mostly comes from me not being able to use their interface)... I almost never have this sort of issue in any other game or game related software.Once, many, many years ago, I had created an account, forgot about it, and then used their little account finder tool to see if I had an account or not. The account finder tool told me my account name didn't exist (when it actually did), so I assumed I must not have made the account. When I found my account by talking to a friend who had it on their friends list, I tried to contact support. But the staff gave me the run around until I told them to use the finder tool with my username. The "fix" is I now have 2 steam accounts, one with just a few games on it. Oh well. I'd like to think they would have come up with better ways to verify user accounts now and let you transfer data, google allows for this. But I doubt it.I have had a few games that I got that don't work anymore (not because of steam), but I blame the game company for that, not steam. I leave a bad review on the game and move on. I haven't tried to return a game I just bought, so I don't have the ability to comment on that.

Steam.body: To cut a long story short, a few weeks ago I posted a thread on the off-topic discussions forum. This game launch has opened up my eyes, because the only way to get support is through an automated system and if you have to deal with people then you may as well just give up. Since I live in Sweden the only currency available is EUR, but to empty the card I needed to use USD because Steam only offer 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 EUR transfers. 50 USD is around 43 EUR and I did not want to lose any money which happened several times doing the top ups in EUR.Anyway, when I was given the card I was on my work computer and since I work for an American company I am always on a secured VPN. This means that I got the option to change to the US region and use USD, perfect! I did it and transfered my 50 USD... but now I was locked for 3 months to the US region. Sure it suck and it is quite a punishment since I did not even buy an item/game or did any trades etc. Then I realised that I could not even buy a game now, my cards, my PayPal .. nothing was accepted because those are linked to Sweden. So pretty much I cannot buy any games AND then I found out that I will not be able to get my pre ordered Steam Deck since it was ordered in the EU region and I am now stuck in US region.The support basically told me:"As for your Steam Deck reservation, you will not be able to complete the purchase as your account country does not match your purchase country shipping address and payment method. I understand that's not the answer you are looking for. Unfortunately, there's nothing more we can do in this case."This is how Steam treats their loyal customers. The worst part is that I bought the Deck for my kids and they are expecting to get it within a few weeks.This is the worst customer experience I've ever had. 17 years as a customer for nothing..

Steam.title: Steam does not follow Its own policies…
Steam.body: Steam does not follow Its own policies and that they changed the prices of a game by stopping my purchase after I already put the game in the cart and hit the buy button.  I was making a purchase of Ark Survival Package when after I put it in the cart and entered my payment information. I received an error message “transaction would not go through” so I tried again and got the same message. On the third attempt with a different payment method I still received the same error but also saw a new error message that they were having technical difficulties try again later. I waited 5-10 minutes and tried again but as I went to my cart the price had doubled.  I immediately open a support ticket to let them know what happen and they admitted to technical difficulties but informed me, I had to pay the new price even though their policy states they will honor the sale price for 72 hours if you have trouble purchasing a game.  The policy states“if your purchase fails, Steam will save your shopping cart (at the sale price) for three days (exactly 72 hours) so you can try to make your purchase again. Any discounts applied to your failed purchase will be saved, even if they are no longer available in the Steam store.So if you're trying to buy a game that's on sale, but you have trouble purchasing, Steam will let you try the purchase again within the next three days.We want you to be able to purchase and enjoy games on Steam. If your purchase fails, the three day period gives you time to sort out the issue with either Steam or your bank.”I quoted their policy and explained that they have the information required to assist me and the final response given was?Hi there,I understand any possible frustration here but we have provided all the available information that we have regarding the matter.With that being the case, I will now be closing this help request. If you do need help with an unrelated issue, please feel free to open a new help request and we will do our best to assist.Steam SupportKurtIs there anything else I can do at this point?

for this sole reason i will try everything i can to avoid further purchases from steam. you do not have a monopoly, i can find other ways to play games. its just sad that something so simple as this can lose so much integrity for your company.

Steam.title: The Ultimate Gaming Destination: My Experience with Steam
Steam.body: I have been a huge fan of Steam for years, and it continues to be my go-to store for purchasing and storing PC games. From the vast selection of titles to the seamless purchasing process and reliable downloads, I have always had a fantastic experience with Steam.One of the things that I love most about Steam is the convenience of having all of my games in one place. I no longer have to worry about losing physical copies or tracking down installation files, as everything is easily accessible through my Steam library. Plus, with the ability to download and play games on multiple devices, I am never far from my favorite titles.I have also had great experiences with Steam's customer support. Whenever I have had a question or issue, I have always received prompt and helpful assistance from their team. This has been particularly valuable when it comes to troubleshooting issues with specific games or resolving problems with my account.Overall, I am extremely satisfied with my experiences with Steam and highly recommend it to anyone who loves PC gaming. The store is reliable, convenient, and offers an incredible selection of titles. Plus, with excellent customer support and multiplayer options, it truly is a one-stop shop for all things gaming.

As parent's that's what you encourage them to do.His experience with Steam sums up corporate (don't care) American business.  As long as you have parted with your money and it's in their account they don't care.Excited 12 year old gets a £50 present from his older Brother and goes online to get the one thing he really wants.  Ark survival for his laptop.  He doesn't check the system requirements properly and after a few hours of trying to get it to work he realizes that it's not going to so he asks for a refund.  Not a chance (2 hour rule that Steam apply is strictly enforced).  Steam are all about money but they are missing the bigger picture which is why they haven't got to and will never be a big player.  Their customer service is worse than Ryan Air.  My 12 year old Son will never buy anything from them again and will never say anything good about them to his mates.  He has been burnt.For anyone wanting to buy something from Steam I would advise this.  Double check the system requirements needed on your machine for the game you want to buy because if you make a mistake Steam really don't give a damn and they wont refund you.  Your money will be in their back pocket and they will give a stock reply (despite their claim of case by case consideration) of 'No refund'. Customer service holds no importance to these guys, shame on you.

Steam.title: They just break the law, and its that simple.
Steam.body: It is amazing how some large American companies just choose to flout the consumer law of other countries over and over again and by making themselves unavailable for comment they get away with it every time. I bought a faulty product, they wouldn't help me fix it despite the law stating that as the vendor it is their responsibility to do so. Then upon trying to get help from the game development team or anywhere else I could find, my trial and error took the game over the "2 hours refund policy deadline". A policy doesn't mean anything if it contradicts law. They can have as many policies as they like but if they sell you a faulty product and (in my case at lease) you can prove a faulty product has been sold, then they should refund, replace or repair. Id recommend that ANYONE that has these kinds of issues contacts the relevant ombudsman no matter how small the amount of money lost is, because these companies will continue to behave this way unless challenged. It is a matter of principle and these companies need to understand they are not above the same laws that govern homegrown companies.

Steam.body: Once upon a time I bought a gift card for steam ($100), when I went to foolishly peel the sticker covering the code (by the way NEVER do this, always scratch the thing like a lotto ticket) and I ripped the code!alas struck with grief I went to steam support, thinking I had effectively just shoved $100 in a blender, but I had forgot I was being helped by *Ta Daaa* STEAM SUPPORT! As I slept and dreamt horrors of never being able to own Cyberpunk2077 due to my own foolishness, the steam support crew worked tirelessly to isolate my problem and resolve my query.I awoke to a well written and polite inquiry from them as to whether or not I had the receipt from my purchase remaining, After a cursory search, tragedy struck! I had misplaced my receipt! After several hours upturning every possible location and sifting through garbage cans, I had no choice but to conclude my quarry was lost.This is the point when most support services would declare yours a helpless case, resigning you to endless transfers and "we're working on it, we'll get back to you" emails. But not steam support! oh no! they ramped it up a notch, assigning only the best of the best to my conundrum (Anne).And so just as I was proceeding to analyze the ripped off sticker under a microscope to possibly glean some sort of clue, I got THE message (and just a few hours after I had informed them of the missing receipt to boot), stating that the issue was resolved!With only the scantest of information the steam support crew had managed to track down my missing $100 and reunite me with my once-lost funds, clearly proving their absolute dominance over all competitors.5/5 service 10/10 service 100/100 service there is not a number high enough to express my gratitude!TL:DR  In just over a day they not only managed to identify the problem but also rectify it. I am now reunited with my once lost steam funds and am off to become the proud owner of Cyperbunk2077! 5/5 service! Scratch your gift cards like a lotto ticket, never peel them & always keep your receipts.
